rComments: Wasn't very interested in Greek history, but his lectures make it interesting with anecdotes and stories relating to the material.

if you're interested in culture this class is not for you. In case you didn't know, Romans didn't really contribute culturally. You'll be learning about the polices of every single roman leader and about what wars were fought where and why. This is what the textbook is about and tis is what the professor is interested in

Want to know what the readings are like? they switch weekly between 100 pages and fifty pages of the most dull textbook, with 8-40 pages of interesting accounts from ancient historians and plays every week, and a nice novel. I don't know why so many people said you'd be fine if you read, lots of the clicker quiz questions  are straight up obscure

There was a lot of reading from the textbook (which could be quite dry) but Hedrick's lectures weren't bad & sometimes he would tell funny stories about famous Romans. He talks very fast & switches the slide fast so write quickly. Just do all the readings to pass the daily iClicker quizzes and go to discussion. No final or midterm(s).

Read read read the textbook and you'll do great!  His in class lectures are sometimes a little off topic and not always representative on the material covered in the daily quizzes, but if you bring your Iclicker, take good notes, and read what he tells you, this class is really enjoyable!

Nice guy. Very knowledgeable about the subject. He makes you read a lot and the book is really boring. Mandatory attendance. His lectures can be a little misdirected sometimes, but he posts his slides online. No final exam.

Fantastic teacher. Quizzes are a little random but he is very straight forward with what he expects and what you need to know for the tests. No midterm, No final, lowest daily quiz score dropped, weekly tests. Very interested in the subject he's teaching. Very knowledgeable as well. Highly recommend!!

I hated this class so much. There was so much reading, online postings, and quizzes, it was ridiculous. And his lectures would be random tangents where he would take 15 minutes to say a  two second point. When people asked about the next test, all he would say was everything from the last test until now. But, he was a nice guy and passionate topic.

Very knowledgeable prof but he tended to talk very fast and go on tangents. There were daily in class quizzes so lecture was essentially mandatory. His tests were based off his lectures and images from the book. Just know the book and lectures inside and out...kinda hard but not impossible

Amazing teacher, very clear, punctual, fair. Class was very quiz/test based--Easy as cake if you DID the reading, hard as hell if you didn't. Section was bi-monthly, with a hot IA who knew her stuff. Tons of reading, but NO FINAL!  Just tests bi-monthly, and daily iClicker quizzes. I'm gonna miss that class!

Class was incredibly padded, homework was reading,discussions split, and no finals or midterms. Tests were short. Attendance was mandatory, but taken with iClickers, so ways around it. Despite being incredibly easy, Hedrick was clearly very invested in the topic and is an interesting lecturer, though he does get sidetracked, which stacked Rdgs.

If his class did not have the hardest quizzes on earth it would be almost perfect. study his powerpoints and book for quizzes. great lecturer very interesting, hardest class ive ever taken, do not take if you want an easy general ed
He's a real man

One of my least favorite history classes taken at UCSC but only because the topic (Alexander the Great) was terrible and the reading/lecture material based mostly on speculation (obviously there isn't much concrete evidence from 300BC but...oh god so boring). Hedrick is funny/nice, he assigned lame 'papers' and tests were impossible to study for.

He's a great teacher but he does tend to go off on random tangents. But otherwise he's insanely knowledable about Greek History. He manages to make the class fun. (e.g. paper on prostitutes in history)

Hedrick is hilarious.  I agree that he can derail his own train sometimes with his tangents but overall the guy knows his stuff and gets you to know it.  Really a good personality and an engaging lecturer.  If you have any interest in history take a class with him you won't regret it.

Professor Hedrick is a really funny guy. However, I must agree that he is all over the place sometimes, he has a tinge of swagger in his personality, and his quizzes feature some ambiguous questions. In addition, his quizzes were always 25 questions. If you get 3 wrong, you already have a B. Couple this with questions that could go either way!

One of the best lecturers on campus, period. If you think his class his hard or his tests are difficult, you either NEVER went to class or are monumentally stupid. That may sound harsh but his tests are so freaking easy...you can ace them just from the lecturers, nevermind the reading. They are also multiple choice. Don't miss out on his classes.

This guy is hillarious. He has so mcuh trouble working a slide show (not power point, slides in those old schhol machines). HE has random jokes, all the time and best of all when he talks about the Ancient greek sex life, really gay pics on pots, etc. he bluches so much and can barely spit out the words. good class

I have mixed emotions about Hedrick. I think he is a very intelligent professor, and he can definetly make you laugh, but I found the lectures unclear and hard to follow. Also, his test and reading assingments were WAY too hard for a lower-division class. However, you can tell he's passionate about the subject, and an all-around good guy.

WORST teacher Ever! Impossible to follow his lectures. Retarded test questions. More reading than my other 2 classes combined. Do NOT take this class if you're not a History major, it's not worth it.  He might be a "funny" guy, but he can't teach for****.

Hedrick is one of the best lecturers on campus. This year, the seminar was on minoan crete which is not my cup of tea, but his classes are always awesome. He's a great guy, and to the person who felt intimidated, you should go to the Classics Happy Hour, and you'll see how great he is. As are the rest of the classics people!

Knowladgable Professor, however, his personality outside of class creates difficulties. He acts aggressive if you questions his lectures and is cocky about his education. He is niether open to comments nor criticism on his teaching style and lectures. He is an old timer (old school Professor) closed minded that needs to remember that college is about challenging ideas and proving them right.
Probably one of the funniest, most random people I know.

Charles Hedrick is the nicest professor.  He is so excited about everything he teaches that you can't help but get excited too.  I had a seminar with him with tow other people, he was helpful and inspiring.  He writes an excellent letter of recommendation
One of the two best Professor's at UCSC.  Entertaining, a wealth of knowledge, and kept the class flowing.  Take any class you can from Charles Hedrick or Brian Catlos, you won't regret it.

Funny guy but lectures are totally disorganized and impossible to follow. Assignments were tolerable only because the TA was there to help. Tests were hard and readings were long and boring. I hated section, but it was impossible to follow his train of thought so sections quite possibly saved me.
A great teacher!  Very enthusiastic and interesting.  You can get an A as long as you attend class regularly and do at least some of the reading.
Tons of energy, extremely intelligent, diverse lectures, and fun!  Hedrick is an excellent teacher...don't miss the opportunity to take one of his classes (this is my second with him).

He's is great. Why come to sc if not to get an old surfer in sandals and tshirts teaching ancient history as if he had firsthand knowledge. Names roll of his tounge like nothing and he can go off on wild tangents. Doesn't like to give study guides more than 24 hrs in advance of tests.
Hedrick puts a ton of work into his classes.  This means he expects you to do the work.  If you care about learning, you will thrive in his classes, and learn a lot.  Check out his web site!!

Coming out of LTIN1&2, the class was a great shock, as was the first exam.  However, Hedrick is great. He pushes you to do your best. The class was interesting and fun.  I really liked him! Cool clothes. LoL

Great lectures, I felt like he knew Nero! Very animated and humorous.  Lots of reading, but not necessary if you attend lecture.  Assignments didn't seem too bad but only did ok 'cause I had an awful TA (Avoid Marina Sarran, very unfair/biased).

For those of us coming out of Latin 1&2, Hedrick's attention to the fine points of latin grammer was a shock.  But in general he's quite forgiving, not particularly hard, and funny in a weird kind of way.  Not bad.

Doesn't go into detail when giving assignments. He is a hard grader, and his assignments are unclear. The reading is boring and long, but hes a funny (ha ha funny) guy that gives pretty good lectures.

I took (am taking) Athenian Democracy, and I have to say that he is one of my favorite professors. His lectures are very interesting, and he is very enthusiastic about his subject, and it's infectious. The class is challenging, but not hard. Effort req'rd
his quizzes are easy, his sections are boring with biased TAs, his lecture is very lively and very easy to pass
bad, never take this teacher.  Hes nice but really hard grader.. This class was my only C in college.  I suggest not to take this teacher.  Very hard.

I took Classical World: Rome with him.  The class had a LOT of reading, but it wasn't crucial. He was very enthusiastic about his field and it came through in his lectures, which I always found facinating. He conjured up Ancient Rome and gave it life.
